resources.string: 48 Laws Of Power
Law 1
Never Outshine the Master

Make those above you feel comfortably superior. Avoid making your talents seem too obvious, or you might inspire fear and insecurity. Let your masters appear more brilliant than they are, and you will attain the heights of power.
Law 2
Never put too Much Trust in Friends, Learn how to use Enemies
Friends can easily become envious and betray you. A former enemy, having already proven their loyalty through reconciliation, can be more trustworthy. Hire them, for they have more to prove.
Law 3
Conceal Your Intentions

Keep people off-balance and in the dark by never revealing the purpose behind your actions. If they have no clue what you are up to, they cannot prepare a defense. Guide them down the wrong path and then strike.
Law 4
Always Say Less Than Necessary
The more you say, the more likely you are to say something foolish. Powerful people impress by saying little. When you are silent, you appear in control. Be precise and purposeful with your words.
Law 5
So Much Depends on Reputation – Guard it with your Life

Your reputation is the cornerstone of your power. Use your reputation to intimidate and win. Once it slips, however, you are vulnerable and will be attacked on all sides. Make your reputation unassailable.
Law 6
Court Attention at all Cost
It is better to be slandered and attacked than to be ignored. Everything is judged by its appearance; what is unseen counts for nothing. Never let yourself get lost in the crowd.
Law 7
Get others to do the Work for you, but Always Take the Credit
Use the wisdom, knowledge, and legwork of others to further your own cause. Not only will such assistance save you valuable time and energy, it will give you a godlike aura of efficiency and speed.
Law 8
Make other People come to you – use Bait if Necessary
When you force the enemy to act, you are in control. It is always better to make your opponent come to you, abandoning his own plans in the process. Lure them with valuable gains.
Law 9
Win through your Actions, Never through Argument
Any momentary triumph you gain through argument will be overshadowed by the resentment and ill will you create. Demonstrate your points through undeniable actions, not petty debate.
Law 10
Infection: Avoid the Unhappy and Unlucky
Emotional states are as infectious as diseases. You can die from someone else\'s misery. Do not associate with those who bring you down or attract misfortune. They will drain your power.
Law 11
Learn to Keep People Dependent on You
The more people rely on you, the more freedom you have. To maintain your independence, you must always be needed and wanted. The more others depend on you, the more power you wield.
Law 12
Use Selective Honesty and Generosity to Disarm your Victim
One sincere and honest move will cover over dozens of dishonest ones. Open-hearted gestures of honesty and generosity bring down the guard of even the most suspicious people.
Law 13
When Asking for Help, Appeal to People\'s Self-Interest, Never to their Mercy or Gratitude
If you need to ask for help, make sure your request appeals to the other person\'s personal interests. Your cause or your gratitude means nothing to them. What can you offer them in return?
Law 14
Pose as a Friend, Work as a Spy
Knowing about your rival is critical. Use strategic conversations to learn valuable information. Ask indirect questions to get people to reveal their weaknesses and plans.
Law 15
Crush Your Enemy Totally
All great leaders since Moses have known that a feared enemy must be crushed completely. If you leave even one ember smoldering, it will eventually ignite. Show no mercy.
Law 16
Use Absence to Increase Respect and Honor
Too much circulation makes the price go down. The more you are seen and heard from, the more common you appear. Withdraw yourself for a time to increase your value and prestige.
Law 17
Keep Others in Suspended Terror: Cultivate an Air of Unpredictability
Behavior that seems to have no consistency or purpose will keep others off-balance. They will waste time trying to figure out your next move. Unpredictability is a powerful tactical weapon.
Law 18
Do Not Build Fortresses to Protect Yourself – Isolation is Dangerous
Isolation cuts you off from valuable information and makes you an easy target. It is better to mingle among people; find allies and be in the thick of the action.
Law 19
Know Who You\'re Dealing With – Do Not Offend the Wrong Person
There are many different kinds of people in the world. Choose your victims and opponents carefully. Never offend or deceive the wrong person, as the consequences could be severe.
Law 20
Do Not Commit to Anyone
Stay independent and preserve your freedom to maneuver. By not committing to any single person, party, or cause, you make others chase after you and bid for your support.
Law 21
Play a Sucker to Catch a Sucker – Seem Dumber than your Mark
No one likes feeling stupider than the next person. Make your victims feel smart and they will never suspect that you are manipulating them from behind the scenes.
Law 22
Use the Surrender Tactic: Transform Weakness into Power
When you are weaker, surrender rather than fighting for honor. This gives you time to recover, time to wait for your opponent\'s weakness, and time to plot your revenge.
Law 23
Concentrate Your Forces
Consolidate your resources and focus them on a single source of power. When looking for sources of power, find a single rich mine that will yield more than a scatter of weaker ones.
Law 24
Play the Perfect Courtier
Master the art of indirection. Assert power gracefully, flatter skillfully, and appear humble while advancing your position. The perfect courtier wields power through charm and social grace.
Law 25
Re-Create Yourself
Do not accept the roles that society foists on you. Forge a new identity, one that commands attention and never bores the audience. Be the master of your own image.
Law 26
Keep Your Hands Clean
You must seem a paragon of civility and efficiency. Use others as scapegoats and cat\'s-paws to conceal your involvement in dirty work. Maintain a spotless appearance.
Law 27
Play on People\'s Need to Believe to Create a Cultlike Following
People desire to believe in something. Become the focal point of this desire by offering them a cause, a new faith to follow. Keep your promises vague and full of optimism.
Law 28
Enter Action with Boldness
If you are unsure of a course of action, do not attempt it. Your doubts and hesitations will infect your execution. When you act, do so with boldness and audacity.
Law 29
Plan All the Way to the End
The ending is everything. Plan all the way to the conclusion, taking into account all possible consequences, obstacles, and twists of fortune. Do not be caught by surprise.
Law 30
Make Your Accomplishments Seem Effortless
Conceal all the toil and tricks behind your success. Your actions must appear natural and executed with ease. This makes you seem capable of greater feats and intimidates opponents.
Law 31
Control the Options: Get Others to Play with the Cards you Deal
The best deceptions are ones that seem to give the other person a choice. Shape the options so that no matter which one they choose, they are playing into your hands.
Law 32
Play to People\'s Fantasies
The truth is often avoided because it is ugly and unpleasant. Never appeal to truth and reality unless you are prepared for the anger that comes from disenchantment. Feed on people\'s fantasies.
Law 33
Discover Each Man\'s Thumbscrew
Everyone has a weakness, an insecurity, an ulterior motive. Find this lever and you can use it to persuade and pressure them. Look for obsessions, vanities, and hidden desires.
Law 34
Be Royal in Your Own Fashion: Act like a King to be treated like one
The way you carry yourself will often determine how you are treated. Act with dignity and confidence, and others will assume you have the power to back it up.
Law 35
Master the Art of Timing

Never seem to be in a hurry—hurrying betrays a lack of control over yourself and over time. Learn to stand back when the time is not yet ripe, and strike fiercely when it has reached the perfect moment.
Law 36
Disdain Things You Cannot Have: Ignoring Them is the Best Revenge
By acknowledging a petty problem, you give it existence and credibility. The more attention you pay an enemy, the stronger you make them. Sometimes, ignoring is the ultimate insult.
Law 37
Create Compelling Spectacles
Striking imagery and grand symbolic gestures capture the public\'s imagination. Dazzle your audience by appealing to their senses, and they will be unable to scrutinize your logic.
Law 38
Think as You Like but Behave like Others
If you make a show of going against the times, people will resent you for making them feel inferior. Express unconventional ideas subtly, while publicly conforming to common norms.
Law 39
Stir Up Waters to Catch Fish
Anger and emotion are strategically counterproductive. Stay calm and objective to lure your opponents into an emotional reaction. Their irrationality will be their own downfall.
Law 40
Despise the Free Lunch
What is offered for free is often a trick. Pay your own way. By being generous and paying in full, you protect your independence and avoid falling into hidden traps of obligation.
Law 41
Avoid Stepping into a Great Man\'s Shoes
You will have to accomplish twice as much to outshine the predecessor who first established the legacy. Instead, find your own niche and forge a separate path to power.
Law 42
Strike the Shepherd and the Sheep will Scatter
Trouble can often be traced to a single strong individual. Do not waste time negotiating with the followers. Neutralize the source of the trouble and the group will disintegrate.
Law 43
Work on the Hearts and Minds of Others
Coercion creates a resentment that will eventually undermine you. It is more effective to seduce others into willingly supporting your cause. Win their hearts and minds.
Law 44
Disarm and Infuriate with the Mirror Effect
Mirroring your enemies, doing exactly what they do, confuses and infuriates them. It also makes it difficult for them to formulate a strategy against you, as you are copying their own moves.
Law 45
Preach the Need for Change, but Never Reform too much at Once
Everyone understands the need for change in the abstract, but on the day-to-day level people are creatures of habit. Introduce change gradually and with respect for the past.
Law 46
Never Appear Too Perfect
Appearing better than others is dangerous. Envy creates silent enemies. It is smart to occasionally display minor flaws to seem more human and approachable, and to deflect envy.
Law 47
Do Not Go Past the Mark You Aimed For; In Victory, Learn When to Stop
The moment of victory is often the moment of greatest peril. Do not allow success to go to your head. Do not overreach in your triumph; learn to stop when your goal is achieved.
Law 48
Assume Formlessness
Be fluid and adaptable like water. By taking a shape, you open yourself to attack. Do not let your enemies know your plans or your next move. Be unpredictable and formless.
